desc.size: Small to medium-sized tree, 10 - 20 m tall, trunk diameter 30 - 50 cm. Crown narrow, rounded, with many short, sturdy branches.

part.partText: light gray tinged with red, moderately thin, irregularly divided into large, scaly plates that give the trunk a slightly shaggy appearance.
stout, square, with short, corky ridges extending between the nodes, orangish with rusty hairs, becoming brownish gray, smooth. Leaf scars crescent-shaped, with several bundle scars forming a U.
dark reddish brown, small, rounded, slightly hairy. Terminal bud 6 - 8 mm long, blunt. Uppermost pair of lateral buds adjacent to terminal bud at nearly the same level.

opposite, pinnately compound, 20 - 38 cm long, with 5 - 11 leaflets (usually 7). Leaflets short-stalked, yellowish green above, paler with tufts of hairs along the veins beneath, 7 - 13 cm long, 2.5 - 5 cm wide, oblong egg-shaped to lance-shaped, tapering at the base, long-pointed at the tip, margins coarsely toothed, thick, firm. Leaves turn yellow in autumn.
have both male and female reproductive organs (perfect); borne in a branched inflorescence; purplish, small, without petals.

dry, single-seeded, winged (samara); in open, long, branched clusters; 2.5 - 5 cm long, oblong, notched at the tip; wing broad, often twisted, extending to the base of the flat seed cavity and surrounding it.

similarSpecies.comments: The square stems of Fraxinus quadrangulata immediately distinguishes it from any other ash in the Chicago Region.

speciesPage.flowering: April to mid-May, as leaves begin to unfold.
speciesPage.habitatEcology: Typically found in calcareous woodlands and wet-mesic sites.

notes.comments: The inner bark of Fraxinus quadrangulata was once soaked in water to produce a blue dye, and its sap will turn blue when exposed to the air. The wood is used for flooring and interior finish, and the tree is sometimes planted as an ornamental. The emerald ash borer (Agrilus planipennis) is a serious insect threat to all native ashes (see link below).

etymology.comments: Fraxinus is the Latin word for ash. Quadrangulata is Latin for “four-angled,” which refers to the square twigs.
